Gross Salary for Employees

gross_salary.Rd

gross_salary() calculates the total earnings from employment before applying deductions for tax-exempt items. It sums up all salary components (e.g., basic salary, allowances, bonuses, etc.) before any deductions are applied.

Usage

gross_salary(...)

Arguments

...

Numeric vectors representing different components of an employee's earnings (e.g., Basic Salary, Allowances, Bonuses).

Value

A numeric vector containing the computed gross emolument for each employee.

Details

The function accepts multiple numeric vectors representing different components of an employee's earnings and returns their row-wise sum. If any non-numeric values are provided, the function throws an error.

The formula for Gross Salary is given by:

$$ \text{Gross Salary} = \text{Basic Salary} + \text{Housing} + \text{Transport} + \text{Utility} + \text{Meal} + \ldots $$

"Gross salary" is defined as: "wages, salaries, allowances (including benefits in kind), gratuities, superannuation, and any other incomes derived solely from employment."

The gross_salary() function is fundamental in payroll calculations and serves as a base for computing deductions, taxable income, and other salary-related computations within the nigeriaPITaudit package.

It supports missing values (NA) by ignoring them during computation. If all values in a row are NA, the function returns 0 for that row.

Note

  • All input vectors must be numeric and of the same length (i.e., corresponding to the same number of employees).

  • The function ignores NA values while summing components.

  • If all values in a row are NA, the function returns 0 for that row.

See also

gross_income

Examples

# Example dataset
df <- data.frame(
  Employee = c("John", "Bassey", "James", "Abigail", "Ruth"),
  BasicSalary = c(120000, 110000, 115000, 90000, 130000),
  RiskAllowance = c(100000, 120000, 13400, 150000, 189999),
  Bonus = c(5000, NA, 7000, 3000, 10000)
)

# Compute Gross Salary
df$GrossSalary <- gross_salary(df$BasicSalary, df$RiskAllowance, df$Bonus)

# View the updated dataset
print(df)
#>   Employee BasicSalary RiskAllowance Bonus GrossSalary
#> 1     John      120000        100000  5000      225000
#> 2   Bassey      110000        120000    NA      230000
#> 3    James      115000         13400  7000      135400
#> 4  Abigail       90000        150000  3000      243000
#> 5     Ruth      130000        189999 10000      329999

# Example 1: Sum of basic salary and two allowances
gross_salary(500000, 200000, 100000)  # Returns 800000
#> [1] 8e+05

# Example 2: Handling NA values (they are ignored)
gross_salary(3000000, NA, 500000)  # Returns 3500000
#> [1] 3500000
